Issues.Title: reset IMG vertical-align
Issues.Body: Heya, I've been following the lighthouse report to optimize our site and after I added a `doctype` declaration I noticed that there was a vertical positioning issue with images which wasn't there prior to adding the doctype ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇ ```html ``` Using the inspector I can confirm that this is not caused by `margin` or `padding`, it's also not part of the image itself. I was able to resolve this issue with the help of a [SO post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/490052) by adding the following CSS: ```css img { vertical-align: bottom; } ``` I'm including `bulma/sass/base/_all` in my build which includes `bulma/sass/base/minireset.sass`. Would you consider adding this to the `minireset` file?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "reset IMG vertical-align" (#2692)

Issues.Title: Fixes #2685: calculate input width taking padding into account.
Issues.Body:
This is a **bugfix**.
Solves input width issue described in #2685 

### Proposed solution

As stated in #2685 the input width is currently set to 100% but the actual width is more than 100% because of the padding applied to the input.

This PR calculates the input width by subtracting the padding on each side of the input to the current 100%.

### Testing Done

I have built the bulma.css file with my changed and tested on the use case described in the issue #2685 that it works as intended.

### Changelog updated?

No.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fixes #2685: calculate input width taking padding into account. " (#2686)

Issues.Title: Input width is more than 100% because of padding
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**. Is it a bug. I have reproduce it both on Firefox and Chrome. (I haven't tested other browsers) ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** [0.8.0] My **browser** is: Firefox 70 ### Description The input fields takes more than 100% of the container. This issue arises because there is padding applied to the input field and it is not taken into account when calculating the input width, which is always set to 100%. This can be fixed by calculating the size as 100% minus the horizontal padding of the input. ### Steps to Reproduce HTML file: ```
``` SASS file: ``` @import "~bulma/sass/utilities/all"; @import "~bulma/sass/elements/box"; @import "~bulma/sass/elements/container"; @import "~bulma/sass/form/shared"; @import "~bulma/sass/form/tools"; @import "~bulma/sass/form/input-textarea"; ``` ### Expected behavior The input should stay in its container with the proper margin on each side. ### Actual behavior The input goes beyond the container's right border.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Input width is more than 100% because of padding" (#2685)

Issues.Title: is-loading wrong css while using colors ( is-danger / is-success )
Issues.Body:
<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
This is about **Bulma**.
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
Its a bug.
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->
Its not browser related.
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
Bulma: 0.7.4
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
Firefox 69
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->
Yep, not duplicated

### Description

Creating a select with "is-danger" and "is-loading" shows the spinning entirely red ( Creating a perfect circle ).

### Expected behavior

Partial circle colored.

### Actual behavior

Full circle red.

### Workaround

.select.is-danger:not(:hover)::after {
    border-top-color: #ff3860 !important;
    border-right-color: #ff3860 !important;
    border-bottom-color: #fff !important;
    border-left-color: #fff !important;
}

.select.is-success:not(:hover)::after {
    border-top-color: #23d160 !important;
    border-right-color: #23d160 !important;
    border-bottom-color: #fff !important;
    border-left-color: #fff !important;
}
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "is-loading wrong css while using colors ( is-danger / is-success )" (#2684)

Issues.Title: Image tag generics rule duplicates minireset's
Issues.Body:
This is an **improvement** that removes a rule duplicated rule between `generics` and `minireset`.

### Proposed solution

Minireset already declares the following, therefore the _generics_ rule for `img` is not needed, and can be removed.

```
img,
video
  height: auto
  max-width: 100%
```

### Tradeoffs

Custom builds that include `generics` and not `miniresets` will lose the `img` rule.

### Testing Done

Checked that the rule is no longer duplicated, but still present.

### Changelog updated?

No.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Image tag generics rule duplicates minireset's" (#2679)

Issues.Title: findDarkColor() not changing the colour
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

I'm not sure if it's a bug or by design.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **0.8.0**

### Description

I want to get a dark version of #e20e76.

Bulma's [`findDarkColor()`](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/35e3ccbd042d137640420cc39f1e8e870b7db618/sass/utilities/functions.sass#L91) function doesn't seem to work; in contrast `findLightColor()` does appear to work.

Is the `colorLuminance()` function supposed to produce the same result as SASS's `lightness()` function?  In this case `colorLuminance(#e20e76)` is roughly `0.19` whereas `lightness(#e20e76)` is 47%.  Which is what [`$target-l`](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/35e3ccbd042d137640420cc39f1e8e870b7db618/sass/utilities/functions.sass#L96) turns out to be here.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set a SASS property value to `findDarkColor(#e20e76)`.  E.g.

```sass
body
  color: findDarkColor(#e20e76)
 ```

### Expected behavior

I expect the resulting colour to be darker than the given one.

### Actual behavior

The resulting colour is unchanged, i.e. #e20e76.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "findDarkColor() not changing the colour" (#2678)

Issues.Title: How to use custom colors (v0.8.0)?
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** [0.8.0] I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** ### Description I read the blog post about [light and dark colors](https://bulma.io/2019/10/15/light-dark-colors/#light-dark-colors) in v0.8.0 but I'm not quite sure how to take advantage of the new functionality. It sounds like if I add a custom color, Bulma will calculate the inverted color, a light version, and a dark version. However I'm not sure how to get hold of these calculated colors. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. I made a `$custom-colors` map in my sass: ```sass $custom-colors: ("foo": #f3488c) ``` 2. I added some html which works: ```html this works as expected

this works too

``` 3. But this doesn't work: ```html oh dear

oh noes

``` Am I wrong to expect that to work? 4. I found another way to get at the calculated colors but it seems a bit roundabout. In my sass: ```sass .bar color: nth(map-get($colors, 'foo'), 4) // These don't compile because there's no such variable: // color: $foo // color: $foo-dark ``` Then in my html this works: ```html ok

also ok

``` Please can you tell me whether there's a better way? Many thanks in advance!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How to use custom colors (v0.8.0)?" (#2674)
